courseName: Build a Sport Sales Network in the USA 2026

intent.oneSentence: Teach operators how to design, launch, and scale a multi-motion sport sales network across B2C, B2B, and B2G in the United States, with explicit rules for partners, procurement, and measurable execution.
outcomes: Design a three-motion system (B2C, B2B, B2G) with separate ICPs, packages, channels, and stage definitions that can be executed and audited.
Run an evidence-based pipeline that prevents false progress, with qualification and discovery artefacts that translate into proposals and delivery handoffs.
Build a partner layer (selection, onboarding, incentives, deal protection, escalation) that scales coverage without breaking governance.
Become procurement-ready for US federal buyers and build a repeatable tender discovery and submission process for EU and UK contexts, with compliance checklists and standard evidence packs.
Ship a 90-day operating plan with KPI definitions, reporting cadence, and risk playbooks that an organisation can execute without improvisation.
nonGoals: Deep product training (this course presumes product familiarity and focuses on go-to-market execution).
Tool-specific CRM certification (we cover operating patterns and governance, not vendor-specific click paths).

concepts.valueChainMapping: Identify who pays, decides, influences, uses, blocks, and governs purchase decisions in sport and fitness.
concepts.segmentMotioning: Treat B2C, B2B, and B2G as different businesses with different economics, evidence, and process constraints.
concepts.partnerEcosystem: Decide direct versus partner-led coverage, then build rules for incentives, deal protection, onboarding, and escalation.
concepts.procurementReadiness: Operate a compliance-first approach for public buyers: requirements mapping, evidence packs, and submission workflow.
concepts.rolloutCadence: Execute a 90-day rollout with explicit gates, KPI formulas, owners, and weekly inspection rhythms.

procedures.name: Pipeline blueprint per motion
steps: Define stages with exit criteria and the evidence required to claim stage progression.
Define stage-level success metrics (conversion rate, time-in-stage, disqualification rate) and what action changes them.
Define forecast hygiene rules: next step, owner, date, and mutual plan required for late stages.
Enforce a downgrade rule: any deal without a dated next step is not forecastable.

procedures.name: Partner enablement system
steps: Select partner types by capability and leverage, not by logo or enthusiasm.
Design onboarding, certification, and playbooks that partners can execute without internal support.
Define incentives with deal registration and conflict rules.
Define escalation triggers, resolution timelines, and a final arbitration owner.

procedures.name: Procurement readiness handoff
steps: Define which public opportunities you are eligible for and which are excluded by design.
Build a compliance checklist, an evidence pack library, and a submission workflow with checkpoints.
Map tender discovery sources and alerting routines for each region.
Align contract terms, risk playbooks, and delivery handoffs so commitments remain executable.

midCourse.deliverable: Pipeline model + qualification and negotiation pack
midCourse.evaluation: Evidence per stage, qualification rigor, discovery quality, mutual plan presence, give-get discipline

final.evaluation: Ability to execute: owners, gates, KPIs, partner governance, procurement readiness, risk controls

lessons.canonicalTitle: Sport and fitness value chain map
lessons.objective: Build a buyer-reality map for a sport or fitness offer by identifying payers, economic buyers, technical buyers, champions, users, blockers, and governance functions.
keyConcepts: buying committee roles (payer, economic buyer, technical buyer, users)
procurement and legal as process owners
seasonality and operational constraints in sport (event calendars, peak periods)
risk owners: brand, safety, compliance, reputation
lessons.exercise: Choose one real offer (yours or a known sport-tech/fitness offer). Step 1: list every party who touches the deal from first contact to delivery. Step 2: assign each party a role label (payer, economic buyer, champion, user, technical evaluator, procurement, legal, finance). Step 3: write one sentence per role stating what they fear and what they want. Step 4: identify the single role that can stop the deal late and write the prevention action.
lessons.deliverable: One-page stakeholder matrix: columns = role, name or function, decision power (0 to 3), success metric, risk, required proof. Include a single paragraph: your primary champion plan and your primary blocker plan.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Segment architecture: B2C vs B2B vs B2G
lessons.objective: Separate B2C, B2B, and B2G into independent go-to-market motions with distinct success metrics, constraints, and operating rhythms.
keyConcepts: success definitions by motion (leading and lagging indicators)
constraint mapping: legal, procurement, data, privacy
lessons.exercise: Create three motion cards. For each motion: define the buyer, the purchase trigger, the time-to-decision range, the primary proof required, and the first 3 KPIs to measure progress. Then write a one-paragraph definition of success that includes: target customer, measurable outcome, and an execution boundary (what you will not do).
lessons.deliverable: Three motion one-pagers. Each must include: ICP header, offer format, sales cycle range, top 3 objections, top 3 proof assets, top 3 KPIs with formulas.

lessons.objective: Build ICP portfolios that separate fit from hope, using explicit fit signals, disqualifiers, and measurable outcomes.
lessons.exercise: Create 6 ICP sheets (2 per motion). For each: write the job-to-be-done, 3 measurable outcomes, 5 fit signals, 5 disqualifiers, and the first proof you would show. Then write a short 'non-ICP' list: who you will not sell to and why.
lessons.deliverable: ICP pack (6 sheets) with a single scoring rule: Fit Score = (signals met) minus (disqualifiers triggered). Include a 'walk-away' rule that triggers disqualification.

lessons.objective: Package offers to match decision structures and risk profiles, using pilots, tiers, and governance-friendly terms.
keyConcepts: risk controls: exit terms, data terms, brand safety
price logic tied to value and delivery cost
lessons.exercise: Build a packaging table with 3 B2B tiers, 2 B2C entry tiers, and 1 public-sector compliant bundle. For each package: list inclusions, exclusions, delivery responsibilities, SLA, success criteria, and an explicit upgrade path. Then write one paragraph: how pricing changes with scale.
lessons.deliverable: Packaging table plus inclusion rules. Include a 'pilot contract' skeleton section list: scope, success criteria, timeline, data handling, brand safety, reporting, exit clause.

lessons.objective: Build a proof system that reduces buyer risk by turning claims into measurable outcomes and credible evidence.
lessons.exercise: Create one proof pack per motion. For each: write a measurable outcome statement with a baseline and a time window, define the data required to measure it, and list acceptable evidence types (screenshots, logs, third-party reports, invoices). Build a one-page case study outline.
lessons.deliverable: Proof pack outline: 3 case study shells + measurement plan. Include an evidence checklist that a buyer can audit.

lessons.objective: Decide which segments must be sold direct versus partner-led, based on margin, control, conflict risk, and enablement cost.
lessons.exercise: Take 10 target accounts and classify each: direct, partner-led, or co-sell. For each classification, write the reason in one sentence and list the minimum partner capability required (if partner-led). Define a conflict rule for when both direct and partner touch the account.
lessons.deliverable: Route-to-market decision matrix: account, route, reason, required proof, owner, conflict rule.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Online channel stack for sport and fitness
lessons.objective: Design a multi-channel online demand system with clear weekly activity targets and quality gates.
lessons.exercise: Design a 4-channel plan (choose from inbound, outbound, paid, community, marketplace, referral). For each channel: define weekly activities, the quality gate (what qualifies a lead), and the handoff rule into pipeline.
lessons.deliverable: Channel plan plus a weekly scoreboard: activity counts, qualified leads, meetings, opportunities created, conversion rate.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Offline channel stack: venues, events, field execution
lessons.objective: Turn offline events and venues into a repeatable pipeline engine with entry and exit criteria.
lessons.exercise: Build a 6-week field calendar. For each event: define target accounts, entry criteria, offer, capture method, follow-up sequence, and exit criteria.
lessons.deliverable: Offline activation plan plus a lead capture specification: required fields, consent rules, and follow-up SLA.

lessons.objective: Design coverage that matches buying patterns using territories, account tiers, and whitespace rules.
lessons.exercise: Draft a territory model for three US regions. Assign account tiers (A/B/C) with rules. Define coverage expectations per tier (touchpoints per month, exec involvement, partner involvement).
lessons.deliverable: Territory spec plus tiering rules and a one-page account plan template for Tier A.

lessons.objective: Prove that each motion and channel is economically viable with explicit assumptions.
lessons.exercise: Build a simple model for B2C, B2B, B2G: CAC, conversion rates, retention/churn, gross margin, payback. Add an assumptions register and mark which assumptions are unproven.
lessons.deliverable: Unit economics sheet plus assumptions register and a 'kill criteria' list (what would make you stop a motion).

lessons.objective: Define stages that reflect reality and force evidence before forecast commitments.
lessons.exercise: For each motion, define pipeline stages and the required evidence to move forward. Add a time-in-stage limit and a required next-step rule.
lessons.deliverable: Pipeline stage definitions pack: stage name, definition, exit criteria, required evidence, disqualify triggers.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Qualification framework for complex sport deals
lessons.objective: Qualify continuously to prevent false progress and protect delivery outcomes.
lessons.exercise: Complete a MEDDICC sheet for one target account. Include: metrics with baseline, decision criteria, decision process, paper process, identified economic buyer, champion plan, competition plan.
lessons.deliverable: Qualification template plus one completed example and a disqualification rule list.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Discovery that drives value and urgency
lessons.objective: Run discovery that quantifies impact, maps stakeholders, and produces a mutual plan.
lessons.exercise: Write a discovery script with: situation, problem, implication, need-payoff questions. Add a short section to confirm decision process and procurement steps. Then create a mutual action plan draft.
lessons.deliverable: Discovery script plus note template that captures: pain, baseline, desired outcome, stakeholders, decision steps, next step.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Proposal architecture: pilot, rollout, and risk control
lessons.objective: Write proposals that are executable: success criteria, governance, and risk controls are explicit.
lessons.exercise: Draft a 2-page proposal skeleton: context, goals, scope, success criteria, timeline, responsibilities, reporting, commercial terms, and exit.
lessons.deliverable: Proposal skeleton plus pricing options table and a pilot success checklist.

lessons.objective: Close with integrity: trade concessions for commitments and protect delivery outcomes.
lessons.exercise: Create a negotiation plan for one live or realistic deal. Define: non-negotiables, tradables, give-get pairs, internal approval limits, and the close plan with dated steps.
lessons.deliverable: Negotiation plan template plus one completed example and a one-page close plan.

lessons.objective: Choose partner models that amplify coverage without destroying governance.
lessons.exercise: Pick 2 partner models and justify them using 5 criteria: capability, reach, credibility, conflict risk, and unit economics.
lessons.deliverable: Partner model selection memo with a go/no-go checklist.

lessons.objective: Make partners productive quickly with a clear onboarding path and certification requirements.
lessons.exercise: Design a 14-day onboarding plan: training, first live opportunity, certification test, and weekly checkpoints.
lessons.deliverable: Onboarding plan plus enablement checklist and partner scorecard fields.

lessons.objective: Create incentive and deal protection rules that prevent conflict and preserve trust.
lessons.exercise: Write incentive tiers and deal registration rules. Include: protection window, required evidence, and arbitration steps.
lessons.deliverable: Incentive matrix plus deal registration playbook and escalation triggers.

lessons.objective: Coordinate partner-owned campaigns that generate qualified pipeline with clear attribution.
lessons.exercise: Outline one joint campaign and one event. Define: audience, offer, capture method, qualification gate, and follow-up ownership.
lessons.deliverable: Campaign and event plan plus measurement dashboard definition.

lessons.objective: Build a partner tool stack and content library that increases conversion and reduces support load.
lessons.exercise: Audit existing assets and define a backlog: what must exist for partners to sell without internal help.
lessons.deliverable: Enablement roadmap plus partner portal content map and KPI list.

lessons.objective: Prepare for US federal buying realities: formal notices, compliance documentation, and process discipline.
lessons.exercise: Create a federal readiness checklist: registrations, standard declarations, past performance evidence, and internal owners. Then create a discovery outreach script that respects procurement boundaries.
lessons.deliverable: Federal readiness checklist plus outreach script and a standard evidence pack index.

lessons.objective: Build a tender discovery system for EU and UK contexts with monitoring, filtering, and pursuit planning.
lessons.exercise: Define your search taxonomy (keywords, categories, geographies). Build a weekly monitoring routine and a pursuit decision checklist. Then map three sample opportunities to: fit, eligibility, and next action.
lessons.deliverable: Tender discovery map plus pursuit plan template (roles, deadlines, submission checkpoints).

lessons.objective: Create an operating cadence that forces inspection, accountability, and forecast discipline.
lessons.exercise: Design weekly and monthly cadences. Define scorecards with leading and lagging indicators per motion. Include downgrade rules and required next-step rules.
lessons.deliverable: Ops cadence plan plus scorecard template and a one-page governance charter.

lessons.objective: Build a practical intelligence stack that improves targeting, timing, and message relevance without data chaos.
lessons.exercise: Define: the minimum account fields you require, the source of truth for each field, and update rules. Then define an intent monitoring rule and an outreach trigger.
lessons.deliverable: Account intelligence blueprint plus a data dictionary and a monitoring playbook card.

lessons.objective: Create motion-specific enablement that produces repeatable execution and certification criteria.
lessons.exercise: Sketch 3 enablement modules (one per motion). Each must include: skills, artefacts, a certification test, and a coaching cadence.
lessons.deliverable: Enablement curriculum map plus certification criteria and a playbook update workflow.

lessons.objective: Align marketing, sales, partners, and delivery through handoffs, shared definitions, and enforceable governance.
lessons.exercise: Define the handoff from sales to delivery: required fields, success criteria, scope, risks, and owners. Define partner-sourced opportunity rules for attribution and evidence.
lessons.deliverable: Revenue ops alignment plan plus process map and a handoff checklist.

lessons.objective: Create a launch readiness system with gates, owners, and measurable early indicators.
lessons.exercise: Build a launch checklist across all motions. Define: gate conditions, owners, and required assets. Define the first 4-week KPI set and review actions.
lessons.deliverable: 90-day launch checklist plus communications plan and assumptions register.

lessons.objective: Define KPI formulas, reporting cadence, and review actions so metrics drive decisions, not decoration.
lessons.exercise: Define KPIs per motion with formulas and owners. Define a weekly reporting calendar and the decision actions triggered by each KPI.
lessons.deliverable: KPI deck outline plus reporting calendar and KPI definition dictionary.

lessons.objective: Identify predictable risks (deal, partner, procurement, delivery) and create escalation playbooks with owners and timelines.
lessons.exercise: Define the top 10 risks and write: trigger, impact, mitigation, escalation owner, and time box. Include a post-signature risk checklist.
lessons.deliverable: Risk playbook plus escalation map and a post-signature success protection checklist.

lessons.objective: Synthesize the system into a single operating plan that can be executed, measured, and improved.
lessons.exercise: Assemble the final blueprint: motions, ICPs, packages, channels, pipeline, partners, procurement readiness, KPIs, and risks. Produce a 90-day plan with weekly milestones.
lessons.deliverable: Complete blueprint plus 90-day operating cadence: weekly agenda, scorecards, review actions, and change log rules.

midCourse.deliverable: Pipeline + qualification pack (MEDDICC + SPIN + close plan)
midCourse.gate: Instructor or admin review for evidence and execution quality

final.gate: Executive review and approval of KPIs, partner rules, and procurement readiness
